title: New Zealand negotiates Southland highway maintenance contract with SouthRoads
text:
New Zealand negotiates Southland highway maintenance contract with SouthRoads 21 September 2015 Print Email 
The New Zealand Transport Agency (NZTA) is in talks with a consortium led by SouthRoads over maintenance of the Southland state highway network. 
SouthRoads has been selected as the preferred supplier for the new $64m contract, which is designed to offer greater efficiencies to the government in terms of operation and costs. 
New Zealand Transport Agency southern business manager (acting) Ian Duncan said: "The network outcomes contracts are a new way of doing business. In the past, there have been a number of contracts delivering the maintenance works on the network. "The network outcomes contracts are a new way of doing business." 
"With one contract for the whole area, for all of Southland except the Milford Road (SH94 Te Anau to Milford), the transport agency is expecting savings across the board." 
Expected to be awarded next month, the contract is said to be performance-based, and will primarily focus on the delivery of good quality outcomes for the network and all road users. 
Duncan said: "SouthRoads have been working on the Northern Southland state highway network for the last seven years, undertaking the general maintenance and keeping roads operating safely over winter. 
"The company has established depots throughout the area and have a good working knowledge of the region." 
SouthRoads have collaborated with professional engineering services provider MWH and contracting companies Downer NZ, McDonough Contracting and Carran Scott Contracting to execute the new contract. 
Work under the contract will start on 1 March 2016, and is scheduled to run over the next seven years. Follow Us:
